original_content:
Here at Hackaday were suckers for old abandoned technologies, the more obscure the better. The history of the telephone has plenty to capture our attention, and its from that arena that something recently floated past our timeline. [IanVisits] reports a sighting of a Rabbit in a London Underground station. The bunny in question definitely isnt hopping though, its been dead for more than three decades. Its a base station for a failed digital mobile phone system.
Weve had a look in the past at CT2, the system this Rabbit base station once formed part of. It was an attempt to make an inexpensive phone system by having the handsets work with fixed base stations rather than move from cell to cell. It was one of the first public digital mobile phone systems, but the convenience of a phone that could both receive calls and make them anywhere without having to find a base station meant that GSM phones took their market.
The one in Seven Sisters tube station is a bit grubby looking, but its not the only survivor out there in the field. We have to admit to being curious as to whether its still powered on even though its backhaul will be disconnected, as in our experience its not uncommon for old infrastructure to be left plugged into the wall for decades, unheeded. Does anyone fancy sniffing for it with a Flipper Zero?
title: ロンドン地下鉄で見つかった"Rabbit": ３０年以上前のモバイル電話基地局
body: Hackadayは古い技術に興味を持っており、最近、ロンドンの地下鉄駅でRabbitと呼ばれるデジタルモバイル電話システムの基地局が見つかった。CT2システムは低価格のモバイル電話システムを提供するための試みでしたが、GSM電話に市場を奪われました。Seven Sisters駅にあるRabbit基地局のほかにも生存者がいるかもしれない。
titles: ロンドン地下鉄で見つかった"Rabbit": ３０年以上前のモバイル電話基地局
CT2システムとは？Rabbitと呼ばれる歴史的なベースステーションの復活
デジタルモバイル電話の歴史：Rabbit基地局が残す過去と未来
ロンドン地下鉄のSeven Sisters駅にあるRabbit基地局：その現状は？
Flipper ZeroでRabbit基地局の電源をチェック！活動の再開は可能？
